author: A_Brickset_user
title: i would give this set  four stars
review: i think this set is pretty good all on all and i also like the fact that the siege tower is not made up of one or two large lumpy peices like it would be nowadays.  i like minifigs as well so i like how it comes with several of those.  i also like the fact that they didn't have to make it a huge and elaborate set, they just made a little section of wall because that's all you really need.  finally i will say that i think that i think it was better when the minifigs still had yellow faces like they do there.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: The original Seige tower
review: What is castle warfare without a seige tower, and the first one Lego made was quite good.  A little complicated to put together, but comes with and holds plenty of mini-figures.  As a nice touch there are poles on each side of the base that your minifigures can use to push the tower into place.  The small castle wall that comes with it isn't much, but can be attached to any of the older castle sets to make them larger.  The ladder is also nice and can be hooked onto the side of the seige tower as you travel towards your the fortress of your foe.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: cool
review: i love this set. i got it off ebay and got it yesterday. it it fun. i like the design much better than the new one. it has 2 more figures, a wall, and a ladder for 2 dollars cheaper. well, i got it for more, but oh well.

author: Novelty
title: Under Siege
review:
This set is a good idea, but like all good ideas, it can be improved.  4 minifigs and a horse is about right for this set, but the one thing about the horseman that could be improved was to have given him a knight's lance and a pennant.

One generic wall piece with nothing much on it may seem a bit bland at first pass, but it is actually a very useful piece for building your own mega castle out of the existing non-modified sets thanks to the built in hinge.

The siege tower is tall and blocky, but the little bridge on it can be raised and lowered with a winch.  The design of the winch mechanism is a bit problematic, but it can be easily improved with a few small Technic pieces.  Overall a rather useful set.

author: Ernst
title: Still the best siege tower of all !!
review:
I consider this the best siege tower of all towers Lego offers. Simply because it is the most realistic one. Other theme's give great towers with extra's etc. but this one is just what it is supposed to be, a siege tower. Probably the reason I love all these old sets.

 

Great to built with again a lot of small parts and a good mechanism to lower the board. Very simple but good are the two sticks to push the tower. The shelves on the sides are great and a good construction. The wall is basic but just right with the known hinges to spread it. Everything has been thought of really.

 

Parts are good, the tower is stable with a good mechanism which works very well. One point of critisism are the knights, all are Lion Knights so no enemy to attack. The best part of this set is really the ladder to climb the wall, definitly a great accessory !! The number of knights including one horseman and their variety of weapons is ok for a small set like this.

 

A good playability which, like I mentioned before, would have been better if there had been two kinds of knights, for example 2 Lion Knights and 2 Black Falcon Knights. But hey, borrow some knights from your other sets and you're in business.

 

Value for money is ok in two ways : according to Bricklink it is about â‚¬40,00 average which I think is the true value if complete (with ladder) for a set like this. I was lucky to buy it for a real steal including the original box so 5 bricks for me personally here.

author: SirSven7
title: Lego Steve's Review
review:
One question arises with this set, who exactly is attacking the castle walls? Sure we have four figs but they are all on the same side, and yes we have a castle wall and siege tower but our Crusaders seem in possession of both, odd, very odd.

 Strong points with this set are the realistic tower (which is a personal favourite of mine) and the cool ladder, this is a very good add-on set, but it needs others to reach its full potential.

If you like this review click on the link to find it and all reviews of the Castle sets

http://legosteveblog.blogspot.com/2011/08/lego-castle-crusaders-sets-1984-1992.html

author: goldenbane
title: Breach the walls, and attack!
review: I never owned this set as a child, but got my hands on it later as an adult.  HOWEVER, a neighbour boy did own it, and we spent many hours battling for control of the wall!  It was always so much fun, and I think kids today would still love playing with this set, especially if they had access to other Lego castle sets!

author: mediAFOL
title: Panels, panels, everywhere
review:
Another in the so-called castle wall collection, the Siege Tower comes with a nice collection of minfigs and accessories. The wall section differs slightly from others such as #6040, #6041, and #6067 in being hinged, allowing more flexibility when these sets are combined.

The familiar 80s Castle issues are present, with wall panels forming the majority of construction. Seeing them used even in the tower itself is disappointing. The choice of black for the tower also gives a very strange appearance, since such things would presumably normally have been fairly roughly constructed from wood.

The tower's drawbridge is nicely done, with the thread passed through four eyelets. As such, as a play feature, it does work well, and the tower's crenellations look splendid.

However, the slightly depressing palette of 80s Castle persists - grey and black on a box-art background of fiery desert yellow simply doesn't delight as it should.
